subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Keyboard mappings and keyboard layouts
msgSnippet: Thanks for uploading this file. It s good to have several ways to look at the proposals, so this is good. I m glad that you indicated the source document and
messageBody:
Thanks for uploading this file. It's good to have several ways to look
at the proposals, so this is good. I'm glad that you indicated the
source document and date. QS-Nu has been updated since then. (See the
file 'qs_keybd_proposals.csv' and earlier email discussion.) I expect
there to be more changes to the proposals over the next couple of
weeks. I was afraid this might happen, with multiple documents
summarizing all of the proposals. As long as everything is in sync at
the end of January, we should be able to avoid confusion when we vote.

I haven't used SCIM, but I can see how it would be useful.

Ted


On Jan 6, 2008 6:11 PM, Anthony Hagan <anthonydh@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I've uploaded a pdf file (qs_keybd_proposals-grid.pdf) based on
> Moira's spreadsheet, which shows the proposed keyboard mappings laid
> out on a keyboard-like grid. This is how I would prefer to make
> comparisons, and I've posted it in case anyone else finds it useful.
> I might later tweak it to include Moira's indications of levels of
> consensus.
>
> If we settle on a mapping which includes the senior letters, I'd like
> to use a tool like SCIM (www.scim-im.org) to automate the use of the
> alternative forms and half letters. This would automatically replace
> junior forms with appropriate senior forms as you type, e.g.
> typing /ys/ (in QS-SAMPA) would result in /Vs/ on the screen. I've
> already tried this for the ligatures in Paul Tremblay's Thoth fonts,
> and it works quite nicely. Of course the hard work would be drawing
> up the table of automatic replacements to insert. (Sorry Windows and
> Mac users, SCIM is a Linux tool.) Has anyone else used SCIM?
>
> Anthony DH
>
>

Thanks for uploading this file. It's good to have several ways to look
at the proposals, so this is good. I'm glad that you indicated the
source document and date. QS-Nu has been updated since then. (See the
file 'qs_keybd_proposals.csv' and earlier email discussion.) I expect
there to be more changes to the proposals over the next couple of
weeks. I was afraid this might happen, with multiple documents
summarizing all of the proposals. As long as everything is in sync at
the end of January, we should be able to avoid confusion when we vote.

I haven't used SCIM, but I can see how it would be useful.

Ted

>  If we settle on a mapping which includes the senior letters, I'd like
